Binary Search Trees

Introduction to Binary Trees

A binary tree is a data structure made up of nodes, each of which has a data value associated with it. Each node has exactly two child subtrees: a left child and a right child, either (or both) of which may be empty. We refer to the top-most node of a binary tree as its root. For example, this diagram depicts a binary tree:

In the example above, the node containing 1 is the root. It has two children: the node containing 2 and the node containing 3. The left child of the node containing 4 is the node containing 8, and the right child of the node containing 4 is empty.

Sometimes, for convenience, we draw binary trees without explicitly depicting empty children. The example above can thus also be drawn as follows:

We can implement a binary tree in Python as follows:

class Node: def __init__(self, v): self.left = None self.right = None self.val = v

To construct the binary tree drawn above, we could then use the following code:

node1 = Node(1) node2 = Node(2) node3 = Node(3) node4 = Node(4) node5 = Node(5) node6 = Node(6) node7 = Node(7) node8 = Node(8) node4.left = node8 node2.left = node4 node2.right = node5 node3.left = node6 node3.right = node7 node1.left = node2 node1.right = node3

Introduction to Binary Search Trees (BSTs)

A binary search tree (BST) is a binary tree with three invariants:

  1. All values in the tree are unique.
  2. Each node value is greater than all values in its left child.
  3. Each node value is less than all values in its right child.

For example, here is a binary search tree:

If you look at, for example, the node containing 3, you will see that all values to its left are less than 3 (1 and 2) and all values to its right are greater than 3 (4, 6, and 7). This pattern must be true of all nodes in a binary search tree.

Why are binary search trees important?

Binary search trees are important because there are efficient algorithms that support the following operations:

  • Determining whether a value is in a BST.
  • Inserting a value into a BST.
  • Removing a value from a BST.

Task 1: Searching in a BST

Using the BST invariants, we can efficiently traverse a BST to search it for a particular value.

First, use the buttons below to demonstrate how you believe the BST search algorithm should work to achieve the given task.

You can then click the “Generate Code Based on Completed Demonstrations” to have the computer generate code that matches the demonstrations you give. This will delete any code that you have written in the text box below.

Note: If your demonstrations are incorrect or do not handle all the necessary cases, the generated code may be incorrect or incomplete. At any time, you can restart or delete demonstrations using the buttons in the “Your Demonstrations” list to the right of the tree.
